module.name: fpJsonApply
module.short: Apply elements from one JSON object to another
module.descr: This unit provides the TJSONApplier component class for merging JSON objects. It allows applying (merging) elements from one JSON object to another with various configuration options for ownership control, case sensitivity, type handling, and output formatting.

element.name: Classes
element.short: Standard component and streaming classes

element.name: SysUtils
element.short: System utility functions and types

element.name: fpJSON
element.short: JSON data structure classes and functions

element.name: TOwnsJSON
element.short: Enumeration values for JSON object ownership control
element.descr:
The TOwnsJSON enumeration defines which JSON objects are owned by the TJSONApplier component. When a JSON object is owned, it will be automatically freed when the component is destroyed or when a new object is assigned.
ojSource The source JSON object is owned by the applier component ojApply The apply JSON object is owned by the applier component

element.name: TOwnsJSON.ojSource
element.short: The source JSON object is owned by the applier component

element.name: TOwnsJSON.ojApply
element.short: The apply JSON object is owned by the applier component

element.name: TOwnsJSONs
element.short: Set of JSON object ownership flags
element.descr: The TOwnsJSONs type is a set of TOwnsJSON enumeration values. It specifies which JSON objects are owned and managed by the TJSONApplier component. Owned objects will be automatically freed when no longer needed.

element.name: TJSONApplier
element.short: Component class for applying (merging) JSON objects
element.descr: The TJSONApplier class is a component that provides functionality to apply (merge) elements from one JSON object to another. It supports loading JSON objects from files or working with existing objects in memory, with various configuration options for controlling the merge behavior. The component can merge at specific paths within JSON structures, handle type conflicts, control case sensitivity, and manage object ownership.
element.errors:
Raises EJSON exceptions when:
Source or apply JSON objects are empty
JSON files do not contain valid JSON objects
Specified paths are not found in the JSON structures

element.name: TJSONApplier.destroy
element.short: Destructor that frees owned JSON objects and cleans up resources
element.descr: The destroy destructor frees any JSON objects that are owned by the component as indicated by the OwnsJSON property. It also frees the destination JSON object if it differs from the source JSON object.

element.name: TJSONApplier.Execute
element.short: Executes the JSON merge operation from apply JSON to source JSON
element.descr: The Execute method performs the main JSON merge operation. It loads the source and apply JSON objects from files if they are not already set, then applies the elements from the apply JSON object to the source JSON object. The result is stored in the DestJSON property. If file paths are specified, it starts merging at those specific locations within the JSON structures. If a destination filename is specified, the result is automatically saved to that file.
element.errors:
Raises EJSON exceptions when:
Source JSON object is empty
Apply JSON object is empty
JSON files do not contain valid JSON objects
Specified source or apply paths are not found or do not point to JSON objects

element.name: TJSONApplier.SourceJSON
element.short: Source JSON object to merge into
element.descr: The SourceJSON property holds the source JSON object that serves as the base for the merge operation. If not set directly, it will be loaded automatically from the file specified in SourceFileName when Execute is called. When a new value is assigned, any previously owned source JSON object is freed.

element.name: TJSONApplier.ApplyJSON
element.short: JSON object containing elements to apply to the source
element.descr: The ApplyJSON property holds the JSON object whose elements will be merged into the source JSON object. If not set directly, it will be loaded automatically from the file specified in ApplyFileName when Execute is called. When a new value is assigned, any previously owned apply JSON object is freed.

element.name: TJSONApplier.DestJSON
element.short: Destination JSON object containing the merge result
element.descr: The DestJSON property contains the result of the merge operation after Execute is called. If CloneSource is True, this will be a clone of the source JSON object. If CloneSource is False, this will be the same reference as the source JSON object. This property is read-only and is set automatically during the merge operation.

element.name: TJSONApplier.OwnsJSON
element.short: Set specifying which JSON objects are owned by the component
element.descr: The OwnsJSON property is a set of TOwnsJSON values that specifies which JSON objects are owned and managed by the component. Owned objects are automatically freed when the component is destroyed or when new objects are assigned. This property is automatically updated when JSON objects are loaded from files.

element.name: TJSONApplier.SourceFileName
element.short: Filename to load source JSON from if SourceJSON is not set
element.descr: The SourceFileName property specifies the file path from which to load the source JSON object. If SourceJSON is not set when Execute is called, the JSON object will be loaded from this file. When loaded from file, the component will take ownership of the JSON object.

element.name: TJSONApplier.SourcePath
element.short: JSON path in source object where merging should start
element.descr: The SourcePath property specifies a JSON path within the source JSON object where the merge operation should begin. If empty, merging starts at the root of the source object. The path must point to an existing JSON object within the source structure. JSON paths use dot notation to navigate nested objects.

element.name: TJSONApplier.ApplyFileName
element.short: Filename to load apply JSON from if ApplyJSON is not set
element.descr: The ApplyFileName property specifies the file path from which to load the apply JSON object. If ApplyJSON is not set when Execute is called, the JSON object will be loaded from this file. When loaded from file, the component will take ownership of the JSON object.

element.name: TJSONApplier.ApplyPath
element.short: JSON path in apply object where merging data should be taken from
element.descr: The ApplyPath property specifies a JSON path within the apply JSON object from which elements should be merged. If empty, elements are taken from the root of the apply object. The path must point to an existing JSON object within the apply structure. JSON paths use dot notation to navigate nested objects.

element.name: TJSONApplier.DestFileName
element.short: Filename to write the destination JSON to after merging
element.descr: The DestFileName property specifies the file path where the result of the merge operation should be saved. If this property is set, the destination JSON object will be automatically saved to this file after Execute completes. If empty, no automatic saving is performed.

element.name: TJSONApplier.CloneSource
element.short: Controls whether to make a clone copy of source JSON before applying changes
element.descr: The CloneSource property determines whether a clone copy of the source JSON object is made before applying changes. When True, the source JSON object is cloned and changes are applied to the clone, leaving the original unchanged. When False, changes are applied directly to the source JSON object. The default value is False.

element.name: TJSONApplier.CaseInsensitive
element.short: Controls whether property name matching is case sensitive
element.descr: The CaseInsensitive property controls whether property names are matched case-sensitively during the merge operation. When True, property names are compared ignoring case differences. When False, property names must match exactly including case. The default value is False.

element.name: TJSONApplier.ForceCorrectType
element.short: Controls whether to overwrite properties when types differ between source and apply JSON
element.descr: The ForceCorrectType property determines the behavior when a property exists in both source and apply JSON objects but with different data types. When True, the property in the source is deleted and replaced with the property from the apply JSON. When False, properties with different types are handled according to their specific types (objects are merged recursively). The default value is False.

element.name: TJSONApplier.RemoveNonExisting
element.short: Controls whether to remove properties from source that do not exist in apply JSON
element.descr: The RemoveNonExisting property determines whether properties that exist in the source JSON but not in the apply JSON should be removed after merging. When True, properties in the source that are not present in the apply JSON are deleted. When False, existing properties in the source are preserved even if they do not exist in the apply JSON. The default value is False.

element.name: TJSONApplier.Formatted
element.short: Controls whether output JSON is formatted with indentation and line breaks
element.descr: The Formatted property controls whether the JSON output is formatted with indentation and line breaks for better readability. When True, the output JSON is formatted with proper indentation. When False, the output JSON is written as a compact string without formatting. This property affects the output when writing to the DestFileName. The default value is False.
